Article.ArticleTitle: Satellite-Based Long-Term Spatiotemporal Patterns of Surface Ozone Concentrations in China: 2005-2019.

AbstractText: Although short-term ozone (<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>) exposure has been associated with a series of adverse health outcomes, research on the health effects of chronic <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> exposure is still limited, especially in developing countries because of the lack of long-term exposure estimates.

The present study aimed to estimate the spatiotemporal distribution of monthly mean daily maximum 8-h average <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> concentrations in China from 2005 to 2019 at a 0.05° spatial resolution.

We developed a machine learning model with a satellite-derived boundary-layer <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> column, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> precursors, meteorological conditions, land-use information, and proxies of anthropogenic emissions as predictors.

The random, spatial, and temporal cross-validation <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math> of our model were 0.87, 0.86, and 0.76, respectively. Model-predicted spatial distribution of ground-level <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> concentrations showed significant differences across seasons. The highest summer peak of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> occurred in the North China Plain, whereas southern regions were the most polluted in winter. Most large urban centers showed elevated <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> levels, but their surrounding suburban areas may have even higher <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> concentrations owing to nitrogen oxides titration. The annual trend of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> concentrations fluctuated over 2005-2013, but a significant nationwide increase was observed afterward.

The present model had enhanced performance in predicting ground-level <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> concentrations in China. This national data set of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> concentrations would facilitate epidemiological studies to investigate the long-term health effect of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> in China. Our results also highlight the importance of controlling <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> in China's next round of the Air Pollution Prevention and Control Action Plan. https://doi.org/10.1289/EHP9406.
